Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Understanding and Engineering the Timing Precision of Superconducting Nanowire Single Photon Detectors

Superconducting electronics and radiation sensors are exceptional for their speed of operation and precision of timing. As a result, they find application in critical niches such as space communications, metrology, sensing, and computation. The performance of these devices thus sets the limit of what can be achieved in these domains. One type of superconducting detector in particular has demonstrated high speed and timing precision: the superconducting nanowire single photon detector. This type of detector is able to detect the arrival of the smallest amounts of light possible, a single photon. As a result of its excellent speed and precision characteristics, it has found application in a wide variety of areas. For example, quantum key distribution, the secure communications method of the future, crucially relies on timing precision of photon detection in order to guarantee security. In a related field, emerging quantum computing thrusts such as those taking place on photonic integrated circuits rely on the precise detection of single photons. Unfortunately, although the speed limitations of the superconducting nanowire single photodetector are well understood, we do not yet understand what limits timing precision (typically referred to as "jitter"), and thus cannot yet engineer improvement. Many theories have been developed that can explain how these superconducting nanowires function. However, none of these theories can justify the jitter seen in these detectors. In this work, we will investigate the fundamental limits of jitter in superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors, and thus enable improvements in a wide array of application areas. For example, communication data rates depend directly on the jitter because the standard low- power digital communication protocol, pulse-position-modulation, uses timing precision to enhance the data rate. By investigating and characterizing possible sources of timing jitter in these detectors, this work will directly increase the impact of the relevant applications in industry, space, and defense.
Although superconducting nanowires have been studied since the 1970s and have been used as radiation sensors for over 13 years, their picosecond-time-scale dynamics are still not fully understood. Early attempts to explain the timing dynamics in superconducting nanowire single photon detectors focused on possible microscopic origins. In the field of radiation sensors based on superconducting nanowires, some theories related these picosecond-time-scale effects to environmental causes and others to processes intrinsic to the physics of the superconducting nanowires. For example, the hotspot model of the detection mechanism was suggested to explain the time delay between the photon arrival and voltage response as a function of number of incident photons at two different bias currents, but fitting to a theoretical model of gap suppression time was poor and no mention of jitter was made. Later, phase slip centers were purported as the mechanism for the initial hotspot creation but again, no substantive connection to jitter came about from those analyses. In this project, we will probe commonly accepted theories in the field as well as unexplored sources of jitter using both numerical and experimental approaches. We have identified several key components of the nanowire operation that we consider likely sources of jitter: (1) nanowire self-resonance; (2) trapping of vortices; and (3) stochastic elements in the microscopic physics of the hotspot. We intend to characterize the jitter contributions of each of these possible sources, and design modified devices that can reduce these contributions to jitter.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main scientific and technical goals of this project were to understand the physical mechanisms that determine the timing resolution, or jitter, of SNSPDs and to use this understanding to engineer new devices with improved timing resolution. We performed detailed studies of the microwave properties of compact NbN nanowire meanders in which we showed that the nanowire behaves as a high impedance transmission line with a propagation velocity ~4% the speed of light in free space. This work lead to a study of the jitter contribution from the variation in the photon detection location along the length of the nanowire. It was shown that this contribution to the jitter can be reduced by using readouts on each end of the nanowire and averaging the pulse detection time from the two readouts. Subsequent work demonstrated that this dual-ended readout technique can also be used to quantify the jitter contribution from the stochastic nature of the hotspot formation process.

We realized that the slow-wave behavior of the nanowire could be exploited to determine the location of photon absorption based on the time difference between the two readout pulses. We call this device a superconducting nanowire single-photon imager (SNSPI). This was realized using a NbN nanowire in a CPW geometry with a total length of 19.7 mm. This device had a spatial resolution of approximately 20 μm, resulting in the ability to resolve photon detection in approximately 600 distinct spatial locations along the nanowire. The single photon imager results in a scalable approach for high-resolution photon imaging in space and time.

We built on this idea by developing a delay-line multiplexed SNSPD consisting of narrower photon-sensitive regions alternating with wider delay-line regions. This device not only provides spatial resolution based on the time difference between the output pulses, it also enables photon number resolution. Pulses produced by photon absorption in different sections of the nanowire created an interference pattern that show up as a unique fingerprint in the pulse shape. This architecture can perform coincidence detection of single photons over a large number of spatial modes and is particularly useful for integrated photonic quantum information processing.

One contribution to the total jitter is from amplifier noise; the resulting time uncertainty is found by dividing the amplifier voltage noise by the slope of the rising pulse edge (the slew rate). We showed that we could increase the voltage coupling, and hence increase the slew rate, by using an impedance taper to connect the high-impedance nanowire to the 50 Ω readout. Using a taper with a physical length of 77.9 mm, we found a factor of 3.7 increase in the slew rate and a 25.1 ps reduction in the total jitter.

A SNSPD integrated with an impedance matching taper achieved photon number resolution (PNR) capabilities, a property that doesn't natively belong to SNSPDs. It showed up to five-photon responses and has been used to directly observe Hong-Ou-Mandel interference of entangled photon pairs with 98.0% visibility. We expect these engineered SNSPDs to find many immediate applications, such as heralding/rejecting multi-pair generation in SPDC, characterizing single-photon emitters, preparing/verifying non-classical state of light.

The transmission-line properties of the SNSPD were incorporated into a distributed device model that showed good agreement with measured results, e.g. it was able to accurately reproduce the measured pulse shapes from the SNSPI device. Additionally, a new SPICE-based SNSPD model was developed to enable significantly faster simulation of device dynamics than standard electrothermal modeling.

With the realization that nanowire dimensions were the primary contributor to jitter, we designed and fabricated a few-micrometer-long straight nanowire device. In collaboration with JPL and NIST, we used this device to demonstrate a record low device jitter of 2.7 +- 0.2 ps at a wavelength of 400 nm and 4.6 +- 0.2 ps at a wavelength of 1550 nm.These results makes an important step towards probing the fundamental physics of the detection mechanism in SNSPDs.
